There would be a massive outcry.&ldquoWith even a no deal for one week, with no flights to and from the UK, no ships, imagine the economic loss of one week of no economic activity, no personal activity, no financial transactions. That would already be a disaster.                Panicked Theresa May prepares CRISIS SUMMIT as Brexit no-deal loomsOne senior EU official said Brussels negotiators were banking on it being such a disaster that the &ldquocycle of negotiations and the political dynamics will be taken over by the real world.But Brexit cheerleader Jacob Rees-Mogg dismissed the claims as &ldquodelusional.He hit back at Brussels, telling The Sun: &ldquoIt is wishful thinking by an EU establishment that has failed to notice that its grand scheme has failed economically, is devoid of democratic support and is increasingly unpopular across the continent.The top EU diplomats also questioned Brexit secretary Dominic Raab&rsquos positive appraisal of how the UK would cope in the weeks after a no-deal break from Brussels.Eurocrats believe Mrs May would be forced back to the negotiating table with Michel Barnier (Image: )Last week, Mr Raab delivered a speech after the Government released the first batch of a series of more than 80 papers outlining contingency measures in the event of &ldquono deal with Brussels.Among other things, the documents outlined guidance for businesses who could face extra red tape at borders and measures to avoid medicine shortages.During his speech to coincide with the papers&rsquo release, Mr Raab gave a bizarre commitment.He said: &ldquoLet me assure you that, contrary to one of the wilder claims, you will still be able to enjoy a BLT after Brexit, and there are no plans to deploy the Army to maintain food supplies.                BREXIT TROJAN HORSE: Brexiteers call for Tory membership SURGE                 &ldquoNo deal Brexit - Let&rsquos embrace the opportunity But EU sources questioned Mr Raab&rsquos assertion, claiming they &ldquowouldn&rsquot count on his reassurance that Brits would still be able to enjoy a BLT sandwich in a no-deal scenario.In his address, Mr Raab rejected what he branded as &ldquowilder claims about the impact of not reaching a deal.The MP for Esher and Walton also dismissed suggestions the Army and Air Force would have to be deployed to secure food and medicine supplies as &ldquoscare stories.Meanwhile, a former EU chief sparked outrage yesterday by claiming a no-deal Brexit would trigger the break-up of the UK.Dominic Raab recently gave a speech outlining the positives that could come from a No Deal Brexit (Image: )Former European Council President Herman Van Rompuy said: &ldquoWe could end up with a situation in which the EU27 becomes more united and the United Kingdom less united. This talk about a &lsquono deal&rsquo is the kind of nationalist rhetoric that belongs to another era.And EU officials believe business pressure on ministers to reach a compromise and avoid a &ldquocliff-edge outcome will come to a head in the next few months.A senior EU official said: &ldquoThe moment the markets understand this is going in the wrong way, the cycle of negotiations and the political dynamics will be taken over by the real world.

story: If Britain has to rely on World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, UK air traffic control would not be given the rights it needs to operate.This would mean Britain would need an overall agreement to ensure air traffic can function as normal, according to the Institute of Economic Affairs.The majority of UK-based airlines would be stripped of their operating licenses for the 27 EU countries, if there was no agreement in place with the EU&rsquos Single Aviation Market (SAM).SAM means that the UK&rsquos planes can fly in the sky and have the &lsquofreedoms of the air&rsquo.                Italian PM threatens to SHUT DOWN EU's ten-year budgetAs some agreements had also been made through the EU, planes would also not be able to fly in airspace over these areas.These countries include the United States, Canada and Switzerland.Julian Jessop, the IEA&rsquos chief economist, said: &ldquoIf there are no alternative arrangements in place, it would be as bad as the worst fears suggest: planes would not be allowed out to fly.But the report did say the government would still have some opportunity to arrange a solution.Brexit: Planes could be grounded if we leave with no deal May has been warned (Image: )Phillip Hammond has become more outspoken lately about Brexit  (Image: )These included becoming members of the European Common Aviation Area but this would mean having to abide by EU rules.It would also more than likely break the government&rsquos Brexit red lines.The government could also &ldquonegotiate a bespoke free trade agreement for aviation.However, this could mean less access to EU markets and could take much longer to agree.The IEA did say it was very unlikely that flights would be grounded which gave them some encouragementPhillip Hammond did admit it was &ldquotheoretically possible this would happen.Mr Jessop, pointed out there were &ldquoseveral quick fixes to the problem.These include a &ldquotemporary extension to arrangements in use at the moment.

title: BBC Weather forecast UK Bank Holiday Monday weather August 2018
story: The UK might not have seen the end of Summer yet as high temperatures return warming the country and bringing back the hot weather.&nbspBBC Weather forecaster Tomasz Schafernaker warned Britain will finally be able to enjoy some sunshine on Bank Holiday Monday after days of cool air wafting from the Atlantic and heavy showers hitting the country.The BBC meteorologist said: &ldquoIf you want some sunshine this Bank Holiday weekend you&rsquore in luck for actual Monday Bank Holiday because that weather system is out in the North Sea.&ldquoWe&rsquore in between weather systems so that means there is a bit of lull in the weather.                UK weather: Bank holiday Monday to see temperatures SOAR back into 20s                UK weather forecast: Bank holiday WASHOUT to cause TRAVEL CHAOS &ldquoThe sun will come out, the winds will die down, it&rsquos going to feel quite a bit warmer.&ldquoNot a completely dry day because in the wake of this low pressure here in the rain we have a few showers dotted around there for Monday.&ldquoBut the vast majority of us should have a fine Monday with temperatures reaching 20C in the south-east which is not too bad.&ldquoHigh teens in Belfast and Glasgow, as well as Edinburgh.BBC Weather forecast: Temperatures to soar on Bank Holiday Monday (Image: BBC)&ldquoAnd then Tuesday the jet stream is to the north-west of us so this is where the low pressures are in the weather front.&ldquoSo in the north-west of the country it may turn a little bit unsettled.&ldquoNotice these orange colours here towards the south coming out of France, wafting up a little bit of warmth from the more southern clime.&ldquoSo actually a beautiful day for us on Tuesday and warming up potentially to the mid-20Cs.&ldquoWe&rsquove got 23C here but could be a little bit higher. 22C for Hull, which is not bad. 20C for Newcastle.Met Office meteorologist Helen Roberts also forecast a good amount of sunshine and temperatures back into the 20s for Monday.She said: The rain will eventually pull away into the North Sea later on Sunday.&nbspBank holiday Monday is back to sunshine and showers. There will be showers pushing in from the west, but a good amount of sunshine and temperatures back into the low 20s.

title: BBC Weather forecast Britain UK hot weather next weekend autumn 2018
story: The beginning of autumn may very well look like mid-Summer for Britain as the country prepares for some hot weather and sunny spells as soon as next week.BBC Weather forecaster Alina Jenkins warned the UK will enjoy the soaring temperatures as soon as the cool air from the Atlantic will swift away on Tuesday.The BBC meteorologist said: &ldquoSaturday is the 1st September and meteorologically speaking that is the start of autumn.&ldquoBut as we look into the next weekend, things will start to turn a little bit drier and maybe a little bit warmer.                BBC Weather forecast: Temperatures will soar on Bank Holiday Monday                UK weather forecast: Shock 30C SCORCHER expected to hit Britain&ldquoBecause what we see is this area of high pressure to the south-west of the UK just starting to build.&ldquoYou&rsquoll notice that fronts are never too far away for Northern Ireland and northern and western parts of Scotland so here we can still see some showery rain around at times.&ldquoBut for many, next weekend is looking a little bit warmer and a little bit drier.&ldquoAnd that theme could well continue further ahead as that area of pressure continues to build and our jet stream is a little bit further north.BBC Weather forecast: Hot weather to return to UK as Autumn starts next weekend (Image: BBC)&ldquoBut that still will bring some outbreaks of rain and stronger winds at times for parts of Scotland and Northern Ireland.Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern also predicted a&nbspgradual build of high pressure which will lure in warmer weather throughout next week.This will result in a 30C scorcher in the southeast of England as the whole of the country experiences high temperatures,&nbsp&nbspaccording to WXCHARTS.McGivern said: Into the start of next week, the front of low pressure clears away and then a ridge of high pressure arrives, so many places are fine on Tuesday.By the middle of the week, another low pressure looks likely to push to the north-west of the country, which is where the more unsettled weather will be.It will be drier further south as a ridge of high pressure begins to build.The signs are that by the end of the week we will see high pressure dominating the weather again.It will turn drier as a high pressure builds. The weekend will see below average temperatures, but after the bank holiday we will see an upward trend as high pressure grows.

story: High pressure largely responsible for the record summer heatwave is about to rebuild over Britain, forecasters say.The mercury will climb from mid-week after a mixed bag of sunshine and blustery showers rounds off an exceptional summer.UK weather charts show temperatures hitting the high 20Cs next Sunday before nudging 30C (86F) during the first week of September.Ground temperatures could hit a baking 35C (95F) next weekend bringing a sizzling start to the meteorological autumn.Britons could be in t-shirts and shorts through next month with freakishly warm weather threatening to hold out into October.Exacta Weather forecaster James Madden said the entire country is about to get another scorching taste of the sun.He said: &ldquoIt is time to get the summer gear and barbecues back out as we have a lot left in the tank in terms of hot weather to come.&ldquoAs we progress through he week there will be a gradual transition to warmer more settled conditions as high pressure re-builds, we also expect the sun to return. story: Sir Donald George Bradman: The cricket player was named 'greatest living Australian' before he died (Image: )Born in 1908, in Cootamundra, Australia, Sir Donald George Bradman was an international cricketer.Often referred to as &ldquoThe Don he is acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all times.With a Test batting average of 99.94 he had one of Cricket&rsquos most iconic statistic.It is especially impressive as no other player who has played more than 20 Test match innings has finished with an average of more than 62.                England vs India: Virat Kohli looking to history books to inspire                Son bowled over by cricket tribute to father                Google Doodle celebrates influential philosopher Ibn Sina - who was...                Who was 'father of football' Ebenezer Cobb Morley in Google doodle?Over the course of his 21-year long test match career he made almost 7,000 runs in 52 Test matches.The Australian also led a team that became known as &ldquoThe Invincibles after they in 1948 went undefeated as visitors in a 4-0 series win over England.That was the first time this was ever achieved.In 2008, on the centenary of his birth, a $5 gold coin with Bradman&rsquos image was issued by the Royal Australian Mint.Sir Donald George Bradman: He is acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all times (Image: )The year he turned 31 he already had a Royal Navy ship named after him, called HMS Bradman.In 2009 he was inducted into the International Cricket Council&rsquos &ldquoCricket Hall of fame.His legacy continues to live on with praise from the world of Cricket and Australia.After his death, the Australian Government produced a 20-cent coin to commemorate his life, and he was also the first living Australian to be featured on a postage stamp.

title: edwina dunn colum stem subjects
story: But whatever the outcome, many are being unwittingly set up to fail.For those who go on to study at A level are likely to choose subjects based on what they are predicted to get the best grades in at GCSE.It’s not because our children are lazy, they are going where the system pushes them.Pupils are often steered away from subjects perceived as challenging, such as maths and science, in favour of seemingly easier options.It would appear to make perfect sense. But that’s where we have got it so wrong.It comes as no surprise that nearly 50 per cent of UK schools are failing to achieve the target 25 per cent of A-level entries in STEM subjects — science, technology, engineering and mathematics.The nation is crying out for STEM skills. It is estimated there is a STEM-worker shortfall of 40,000 — and it is set to rise. We are facing a national crisis.Yet schools are rewarded on delivering grades, not different subjects. And this relentless focus on grades means youngsters are potentially being deprived access to high-paid and fast-growing careers.Research shows interest in maths and science dramatically declines during secondary school.When it comes to gender, there is a big difference. Interest in STEM subjects drops by 56 per cent among boys and 74 per cent among girls.Quite often girls underestimate their performance and, although they get better grades in maths and physics at GCSE, fewer of them take the subjects at A level than boys.There is this perception that you have to be a genius to do maths or science, but that is not true.Often teachers will say unless you get a grade A in maths or science at GCSE, don’t even bother taking it for A level. The reality is, even if you get a lower grade in the subject, it is still viewed very well by employers. Even if you take just one STEM subject, it will open up so many more doors.This is one of the reasons I created Future Finder, a free app to show young people the relationship between subject choices and their career pathway.After all, this is about preparing them for a job, not getting them to the top of the school system.Science is also fun, it is creative. It’s not dull and nerdy, which is how it is often perceived.We need to tell youngsters there are such jobs as autonomous vehicle engineers, gamification designers and carbon capture technicians, because you can’t be what you can’t see.Sixty-five per cent of children entering primary school now will end up working in jobs that don’t yet exist. And unless young people are learning the right skills, they’re not going to get them.Nearly 30 years ago, when I set up a data analysis company with my husband Clive, people threw data away because it was too expensive to keep. We went on to create Tesco Clubcard, the world’s first supermarket loyalty card.We were only a small business, but we had the skills to figure out something Tesco couldn’t on its own — exactly what its customers were buying.It revolutionised the way we shop, the supermarket doubled its market share within the year and we went from employing 30 staff to 1,500.We were at the forefront of a new science and it was an amazing time.I’m incredibly lucky and I’ve had a brilliant career. Now I want to help give back by preparing tomorrow’s talent.I was the chair of Your Life, a national campaign to encourage youngsters to consider careers in STEM.As a result of that movement, the Government now gives schools an additional £600 per pupil studying maths at A level.Figures also show that STEM subjects are becoming more popular. More than a third of all A-level entries in 2018 were in these subjects and more girls are taking STEM subjects.But we are already far behind countries such as America and China. That gap is only going to get wider too, as we estimate we will need 1.3million more science professionals by 2030.If schools are the talent factory then we need to deliver the skills the nation needs. We must start by giving extra weighting to maths and physics when it comes to measuring a school’s success.We are defined by the talent coming through our schools. That’s our future, that’s who we will be.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: the sun says british government betrayal
story: Their only concern was providing cheap workers to fuel the economy and, in Labour’s case, to “diversify” the country.So our borders were flung open. And since 2000 our population has soared by more than seven million — more than 80 per cent of it directly due to immigration, according to Migration Watch.The Sun is not criticising the migrants themselves. Quite the reverse. The vast majority come for a better life and a decent job and integrate perfectly.Our objection is to short-sighted politicians who failed to foresee the cost.Now wages are depressed, houses and rents unaffordable, schools overcrowded, the NHS and our transport system under massive strain.Migrant numbers should be tied to our economic need — but it is vital, with the annual net increase still at 280,000, that we build the infrastructure to match.What’s being done? Precious little.WHAT credibility can Labour’s promises over the freedom of the media possibly have when their single biggest financial backer is the odious Max Mosley?Leave aside that he is a former fascist who was present as his father Oswald’s thugs marched through a Jewish area of East London chanting “Jews out”.He now bankrolls Corbyn’s mob, to the tune of £300,000 last year alone, because he knows they will try to crush the popular Press given the chance. His apparent sole motivation being revenge after his lust for Germanic sado-masochistic hooker orgies was exposed.This, then, is the rancid state of Labour:A cesspit of a party, run by public schoolboy Marxist class warriors, infested with anti-Semitic racism and funded by one of the most unimaginably unpleasant individuals in public life.How proud its MPs must be.IT’S far too easy for banks to blame ­customers conned out of their savings.Most of us are still too savvy to give our details to cold-callers or emailers. But the scams grow more and more credible and sophisticated. It’s easier than ever to be taken in and plenty are.The Financial Ombudsman argues that it’s unfair to assume victims are “grossly negligent”, and we agree.The onus must be on banks to beef up their security processes and software to keep our funds safe — as well as to keep hammering home to all customers the risk in handing over information.Last year only a quarter of the £240million stolen got refunded.That represents a shameful shirking of responsibility.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn media reform mick hume opinion
story: Addressing the annual Edinburgh Television Festival, Corbyn declared that the UK news media is “failing”.Presumably the Press was to blame for his failure to answer the same question on Brexit no fewer than six times the day before.Fear not, Labour’s Great Leader has a plan.He proposed a one-off tax on big tech firms such as Google and Facebook.But not to fund hospitals, social care or anything useful.Instead, Corbyn wants to back “news co-operatives” that will produce “investigative, public-interest journalism” and produce a more “informed public”. Corbyn’s speech was full of cuddly sounding expressions.But the real message was clear: Never mind all that freedom nonsense — let’s nationalise the news.So, the Labour leader says he wants to invest taxes in public-interest journalism.Who would want journalism that goes against the public good?But the question is: Who decides what the public interest might mean?Government ministers? High court judges? Simon Cowell and Cheryl? Jeremy Corbyn’s press office?Look a little closer and it is clear there is no consensus on what qualifies as public-interest journalism.It is just an ethical-sounding excuse for imposing your own interests on what are really matters of personal taste and political preference.One thing seems certain: It will not be the British public deciding which sort of public-interest journalism taxes should finance.Corbyn wants his state-backed media fund to be “independent”.A buzzword that should raise the question: Independent of what?There are no independent angels floating above the grubby political battles below, with only the public interest at heart.Everybody has interests and agendas of their own.Labour’s independent media funding body would be another government-backed quango, stacked with placemen from the political and cultural elites.Corbyn had the nerve to protest that the media today is “unaccountable”.Yet his independent media board would be less accountable to the public than newspapers, which must respond to their readers who pay their hard-earned money for their newspaper of choice.As for taxes funding journalism to create a more informed public — informed by who, peddling which line?It is not hard to imagine the sort of information Corbyn wants the media to feed us, it would be like the old Russian Communist party paper Pravda.It is no coincidence that the Labour Party’s biggest individual donor last year was the odious, Press-hating Max Mosley.The Labour leader singled out something called the Bureau Of Investigative Journalism as an example of an independent outfit that should be given charitable status and tax perks.Would that be the same self-righteous bureau that prompted the BBC’s flagship Newsnight programme to throw its ethics overboard a few years ago and falsely inform us that a Tory lord was a paedophile?Newsnight never recovered its reputation in the wake of the debacle.When Corbynites talk about wanting a more “diverse” media, one thing they do not mean is diversity of content and opinion. They want a conformist media that will report what it is told and not ask awkward questions.Even the BBC — bastion of the Remainstream media establishment — is too insolent for Labour’s tastes.If you want to see the real face of Labour’s attitude to journalism, just look at Corbyn’s smirking response to a Sky News reporter who asked him some straight questions about the recent wreath-laying controversy.His contemptuous reply basically said, “You have no right to know what I do or think” — in which case, neither do the mass of viewers.Labour’s track record gives the lie to any notion that it is interested in a more open media.The non-Corbynite deputy leader, Tom Watson, is an even more embittered Press-hater.Who does Jeremy Corbyn think he is, to be laying down the law on what a free Press should or should not investigate, and protesting to regulators when they report facts or express opinions not to his liking?Yet Corbyn’s quasi-Stalinist vision of State-approved journalism seems to go down well with his cultish fan club, who ensured that #ChangeTheMedia was trending on Twitter even before he spoke in Edinburgh.Perhaps they should more honestly have made it #ChangeTheMedia-OrElse.“Just because it’s on the front page of The Sun or The Mail,” Corbyn claimed yesterday, “doesn’t automatically make it news.”If he had his way, it would be more a case of: “Just because it’s news, doesn’t automatically mean it should be allowed on the front page of The Sun.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun says philip hammond brexit gloom
story: Brexit Secretary Mr Raab rightly rubbished the wilder scare stories and said most people wouldn’t even notice the impact of a so-called “hard Brexit”.And he is convinced, like The Sun, that after a potential short-term wobble the country will be better off out.But he was realistic too about banking problems for our expats — plus credit card charges rising and customs duties having to be paid on EU imports.Why did Philip Hammond then issue a letter recycling the Treasury’s absurdly gloomy Project Fear predictions for 15 years’ time? Remainer sabotage? Or just another tone-deaf blunder?Either way, he left the Government looking even more chaotic than usual.Will No Deal happen? Consider this:Britain has offered “unconditional” security cooperation with the EU post-Brexit. In response, Brussels vows to CHARGE us to access its databases.They want capitulation, not a deal.JEREMY Corbyn’s sole motive in “changing the media” is to silence a hostile Press.The giveaway was when he attacked broadcasters yesterday for following up Sun stories. “Just because it’s on the front page of The Sun or Mail doesn’t automatically make it news,” he whined.Could this be because recent front pages have exposed Labour’s racism? That IS news, as page one stories in the two biggest daily papers tend to be.Britain already has the world’s most vibrant media. Corbyn is feigning some high-minded interest in improving it. But the last thing he wants is it holding a future Labour Government to account.He detests scrutiny, as his tantrums sparked by tricky questions prove.As for his plan for a state-run Facebook rival, can you imagine anything more ridiculous or pointless?The ­Austin Allegro of social media, making ­gargantuan losses for taxpayers?And how about his “Netflix levy” to fund the BBC?Is there no limit to the costs he wants to pile on ordinary people?NOW, by contrast, is the time for the Tories to CUT taxes.There is depressing talk of a new hike to fund the NHS. But the public finances are in unexpectedly good shape, the deficit plummeting and growth on the up.Corporation tax should be as low as Ireland’s, stamp duty slashed to get the housing market moving, fuel duty lowered, and income tax cut too.With No Deal Brexit more likely, we need to boost the economy and lure investment with a low-tax regime as never before.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady cbb dan osborne
story: The “theme” of this year’s CBB is that all the celebrities in the house have been embroiled in a scandal of some sort.But I would argue “scandal” is not quite the right word for the events that led to Osborne losing his role on Towie.In November 2014, Osborne was questioned over assault allegations after a fight with his ex, Megan Tomlin, although he was released without charge.A few months later, an audio recording emerged — allegedly secretly taken by Megan in November 2014 at her home — of Osborne apparently making foul-mouthed threats to “knife” Megan if she met another man, and referring to her as his “property”.That was three years ago, in 2015, and he went on to issue a public apology.He lost his job on Towie and also some lucrative endorsements which, no doubt, led to some soul-searching on his part.When talking about the “scandal” before entering the CBB house he said: “I said something that I never ever meant, I’m embarrassed by it. It was a horrible time.”In light of his apology, some people might talk about rehabilitation. He’s said he’s sorry and he won’t do it again.People have to be given a ­second chance — right?Before I answer that, let me flag up a few other stories that caught my eye this week.There’s the tale of Sean Simmons, 28, a domestic abuser from Hull who waterboarded one of his ex-partners, tying her to a bath before covering her face with a towel and pouring cold water over her, saying: “This is what I do to people who lie. I’m going to make you tell the truth.”Later, he produced a knife and said he’d “have to kill her”.And Darren McKie, a 43-year-old police inspector who was jailed for life after strangling his wife Leanne, 39, at their home in Cheshire, then dumping her body in a lake.And Glyn Leedell, 39, who threatened to kill a woman with a kitchen knife within hours of meeting her in a Rotherham pub.Oh, and the news that Ian Stewart, 57, who was jailed for 34 years after smothering his wife, children’s author Helen Bailey, is being questioned over the death of his first wife, Diane Stewart, who died after collapsing in the garden of the couple’s home in Cambridgeshire.I could go on, but it’s too depressing.If you read the same stories you may have taken a moment to despair that the papers are full of similar stories every day — of women being killed, brutalised and attacked by the men who purport to love them.Or, you may have barely noticed because these stories are so ­commonplace.Of course, not all men who threaten to kill their partners go on to do so.But you can be sure that most of the women above had probably suffered years of traumatic intimidation and abuse before their partners actually acted on their threats.Meanwhile, those women were ­living in fear — that’s what these chumps get off on. They want to make their victim feel helpless and powerless.So, let’s talk about forgiveness and rehabilitation.Do I think people who really regret being a perpetrator of domestic violence deserve a second chance? Yes, I do.If someone is genuinely ­repentant about anything they’ve done wrong, you can’t refuse ­forgiveness forever.Do I think that Dan Osborne’s second chance should take the form of a public platform on which to rehabilitate his image and, no doubt, earn a pretty penny or two into the bargain?No, I really, really do not.Sure, it was three years ago and no, he didn’t actually go on to act on his threat to knife his ex.But by letting him into the CBB house, Channel Five are sending a strong message that domestic violence allegations are a trivial affair, not to be taken seriously.By welcoming him in, despite his “scandal”, they are normalising and turning a blind eye to the kind of behaviour that too often ruins — and sometimes ends — women’s lives.People on TV are role models. And to allow a man who has made verbal threats to kill his girlfriend to become a role model is irresponsible in the extreme.ITV recognised this when they decided to boot him off Towie.Channel Five should have done the same.SHIRLEY BALLAS has revealed she weighs herself every day in the run up to Strictly in order to get “telly ready”.You might think that sounds extreme but, believe me, the only way to get telly ready is to take very seriously the old adage that the screen adds a stone.I don’t exactly weigh myself before filming The Apprentice or Give It A Year but, in the three months leading up to filming, I always manage to lose – by hook or by crook – a stone.In fact we all do – Lord Sugar and Claude Littner are watching what they eat as well.Then, as soon as filming stops, we all immediately put the weight back on again as normal life resumes.And, let me tell you, it’s a lot harder to take it off than it is to put it on.I’M a big believer in benefits being available to people who need help because they can’t help themselves.But the story of Bangladeshi immigrant Abdul Jalil, a father of six who came to the UK in 1969, really makes a mockery of the system.Jalil, who is 64, hasn’t worked since 1988 for “health reasons”.But a probation officer found the only problem he had is a slightly tender right knee.In 2008, he exceeded the amount of cash that claimants are allowed to have when he was loaned £25,000 to buy his council house.He did not notify the Department for Work and Pensions and continued wrongly claiming more than £28,000 over the next eight years.He then lied to the DWP about his assets as he filled out his benefits review form in 2012.He had re-mortgaged his council flat in May that year for roughly £148,000 and given the money to his children so they could purchase their own properties keeping around £86,500 for himself.Then at court this week he was spared jail – in favour of community service and even had the cheek to say he would do it if it was “light work”.I know that some people need benefits to get back on their feet, and I’m proud to live in a country that provides that.But once a person is back up, they need to actually stand on their own two feet – rather than abusing the system that helped them.Like all benefit cheats, he should pay the money back or go to jail and never be allowed access to benefits again.AS taxpayers we give almost £14BILLION a year away in foreign aid of which almost £1billion goes to the EU, and this week the Government was threatening to withdraw our cash if there was no-deal Brexit.Why wait until Brexit? Just stop it now.We need this money to fix our own country – our NHS, our police forces, our schools, benefits and housing all need it desperately.And the worst part of all this is that we have to borrow the money to give it away.Our country has almost £2TRILLION of debt, which costs around £50billion a year to service in interest.Borrowing money to give it away, it’s the economics of the madhouse.I KNOW our prisons are full, but it beggars belief that Allan Williamson, 45, was let off with a two-year community order and 30 days rehabilitation.When police raided his flat in Hulme, Manchester, they found more than 600 images – including 68 films classed as Category A, the highest level of children being sexually abused.To be clear, the images showed children as young as seven being sexually abused by adults.Still, Judge Elizabeth Nicholls,  decided prison wasn’t necessary, saying Williamson had been “open and frank” with the police about his behaviour and because the man has allegedly taken “tentative steps to address these issues”.So the guy was in possession of 600 images including many of the worst kind of paedophilia – and he’s still in the community?Who in their right mind would want this guy in their community?I know the prisons are buckling, so let’s just build more – even if that includes sending prisoners out to sea in containers.When is the justice system going to start thinking about the victims as opposed to the perpetrators?I BET the boyfriend of Kay Longstaff – the air hostess who spent ten hours in the water after plunging from a cruise liner – is feeling a bit embarrassed.Longstaff was miraculously rescued ten hours after falling – or jumping – from the Norwegian Star, 60 miles off the Croatian coast last week.It’s not quite clear what happened beforehand but other passengers and crew claim to have seen Ms Longstaff in several arguments with her partner Craig Rayment, above with Kay, on the evening of the incident.Once she’d been rescued, Mr Rayment’s estranged wife Kelly offered Ms Longstaff some unsolicited support, saying: “If I was on a ship with him, I would get off any way I could.”Oh dear.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: politicians dont answer questions
story: I have made my peace with this and accepted, regardless of the fact I have never fiddled my expenses or taken cash for ­questions, some of those who come before me have damned all politicians to the sin-bin.I do, however, think there is one very simple thing all politicians could agree to do that would help rehabilitate us to the public.We could answer a straight question with a straight answer.This week doing the rounds on Twitter was a clip of Jeremy Corbyn on Channel 4 News being asked six times: “Do you honestly believe Britain will be better off outside of the EU?”Each time he answered with a iation of, “Labour wants to maintain good relations with the EU to protect jobs”.His words are not bad — it is certainly the answer he and his team would have practised.But it is not an answer to that question and that’s the problem.To the average punter it just looks like politicians can’t be straight.The answer, as far as I’m concerned, is a big fat no.Gavin Williamson, the Defence Secretary, suffered a similar cringeworthy encounter with Richard Madeley in May.The question in the wake of the Salisbury poisonings was: “You told Russia to ‘shut up and go away’.Do you regret that now?Do you think it was too informal?”He started by answering an entirely different question about paying tribute to healthcare workers, which had absolutely nothing to do with what he was being asked.God only knows why he didn’t just say: “Yeah, it wasn’t my finest hour but I guess I was just really cross that people in Britain were being poisoned.”He could then have gone on to say all the nice things about Salisbury health workers.Instead, Madeley savaged him and all that anyone remembers of the encounter is that Gavin Williamson should avoid interviews.Mind you, at least both Corbyn and Williamson gave an answer.At least they bothered to take part.Boris Johnson would just have offered his questioner a cup of tea as if he was Mrs Doyle from Father Ted.I honestly despair.I’m not sure when the art of just repeating the same message over and over again, even if it in no way answers the question, started.Most people put it down to the Tony Blair years of slick media management, but times have surely got to move on.Politicians spend too much time hedging their bets, trying to keep all the people happy and end up pleasing no one by waffling through an answer that is basically six of one and half a dozen of the other.I get that it is hard when your job is basically a massive popularity contest, but I am not sure we are made more popular by dodging questions and refusing to give our own opinions.People contact me every single week telling me they don’t always agree with me but they appreciate that I stand up for what I believe.I honestly don’t think the British people want politicians to say an approximation of a safe answer, or to try to be pals with everyone.People have a damn sight more respect for people when they say what they think, even if they disagree.For too long politicians have been especially scared of upsetting working-class people, without recognising that most people don’t even think of themselves that way any more.I have absolutely no idea where the idea came from that the average member of the public can’t stand a bit of discussion and disagreement, or are so fragile that they will all fall apart if someone says something not to their liking.I have never once voted for someone who I agreed with 100 per cent of the time.I didn’t marry someone I agreed with a 100 per cent of the time and, frankly, if he tried to please me, placate me and pander to all my views I would no longer stay married to him, because it would be dishonest.Don’t get me wrong — saying what you think is not a universally appreciated characteristic and some do get in touch with me to tell me to shut up and go away.Much like Russia probably felt when Williamson said it to them, I pay little mind to this and crack on.Journalists do sometimes ask stupid questions.Politicians do have to be careful about what they say as it can sometimes get twisted and misrepresented.Things are not always simple, and giving a quick answer on a complex issue takes some skill.All that said, it has got to be time to stop the waffle and give the public a break from shouting at their telly each night: “For God’s sake, answer the bleedin’ question!”IT’S that time of year where slow news weeks turn to how much wine we should drink and if swearing at work should be banned.Apparently no amount of alcohol is safe, which will change absolutely no one’s behaviour, and swearing at work is bad for morale.I cannot agree on the swearing front.I am not advocating we all run around barking sweary orders and aggressive expletives at our colleagues but I find sometimes, especially in times of high stress in the office, nothing will quite explain it like a collective FFS.I have seen how a bit of good old Anglo Saxon can be used to break down barriers between me and my constituents.It stops me seeming like some lofty bureaucrat who cannot understand their problems.In some cases it makes them physically relax if we get a bit sweary about their crappy landlord or their benefits being stopped.We all swear, and most of us drink, I doubt that’s going to change.PADDY DOHERTY of My Big Fat Gypsy Wedding and Celeb Big Brother fame was in the papers this week, leading the funeral procession for his nephew.A sad affair, of course, but the diamond-encrusted funeral casket is reported to have cost £100,000.I remember organising my own mother’s funeral and balking at spending around £2,500 for an event I’d rather have not had to attend.I could hear her voice in my head saying, “How much?” as we wrote out cheques for cars and coffins. My wedding only cost £3k and I thought that was a bit much.When my time comes, I implore my family to keep their cash. I wouldn’t be thankful for money being literally burnt.THIS week’s, in fact this year’s, feminist icon goes to the unlikely Stormy Daniels.There is, of course, no reason why feminism would not extend to women performing in pornography but there are few crossovers.Stormy Daniels is a hero.World leaders across the globe pander to Trump, few are brave enough to publicly call out his racism, sexism and terrible decision making.Our own PM holds his hand, allowing him to make her look weak and feeble.Ms Daniels has been brave enough not only to take on the most powerful man in the world but also some pretty tooled-up lawyers too.After apparently receiving payment and signing a non-disclosure agreement to hush her up about an affair she had with Trump in 2006, she broke rank.This was not just a kiss and tell, this was a story that has caused Donald Trump’s lawyer Michael Cohen to plead guilty to breaking election campaign rules.He explicitly stated that he was told to pay her the money by “the candidate” meaning Trump. Donald Trump will probably get away with this misdemeanour, but it is the closest he has come to being in real trouble.Without Stormy Daniels and her courage to face down legal threats, vicious hate mail and a campaign to discredit her, powerful men would continue to use women as playthings and just pay them off when they are done.Stormy Daniels is every woman who has been messed about and we salute her for fighting back.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: just ignore bogus chancellor hammond the sun is brexing out
story: Of course, she was right to ask.Not a single public authority predicted the biggest crash in modern history — not the Bank of England, not the ­Treasury, and certainly not the Chancellor of the Exchequer.Then in 2016 they did it again. Project Fear forecast dramatic downturns in the economy if the people were so unwise as to vote for Brexit. Wrong again.Since then, we have had record levels of employment, huge investments from the likes of Google, Microsoft, SoftBank and a long list of other companies.They demonstrated their confidence in the future of this great country in the best way possible — with their money.This time round the wise insight came from Andy Haldane, the best economist at the Bank of England.Ruefully he said “economic forecasting is having a Michael Fish moment”.Michael Fish was the weather forecaster who completely mispredicted the huge 1987 storm that struck Britain.If only economic forecasters were even as good as weather forecasters, we would be a lot better off. But they are not, and they are at it again.This week Chancellor Philip Hammond predicted the Treasury would need to raise an extra £80billion in 15 years’ time in the event of a no-deal Brexit.And yet the Chancellor insists on ­trotting out yet another bogus forecast, on the very day that my successor as Brexit Secretary, Dominic Raab, is ­presenting the first set of preparation for no deal.Coincidence? I do not think so.The great departments of state are very careful about what they put in the public domain, and exactly when.For nobody is this more true than the Treasury, which has to judge the public perception of everything it does, if only because of its effect on the markets. So this was either spectacularly incompetent, or deliberate. I know what I think.And even more disgraceful, by doing so it will undermine the Government’s hand in striking a deal with the EU.If they do not think we dare walk away, then they will give us the worst deal they can think of. Bear in mind that the Chequers deal already concedes enormous amounts to the EU.It would not be long before our world-leading position in life sciences, gene technology, artificial intelligence, self-driving cars and a whole range of other modern industries would be being actively undermined by the Europeans.As for being out of reach of the ­European Court, pull the other one.But now the Treasury is beginning to fear that even these spectacular concessions the Government has made in the Chequers deal will not deliver agreement from the European Commission — or if it does, the Commons will turn it down.In that event you can expect attempts by the Remainers in Parliament to try to scupper our departure by delaying it beyond the General Election, or offer some other enormous raft of concessions to give back control of the EU.Hence the ridiculous suggestion that the Army would be used to move food around the country.Why? What conceivable aspect of European policy would handicap British hauliers moving British products from Kent to Cumbria?None of course, but it was just the bogus nonsense some of our Remainer media is only too happy to carry ­completely uncritically. Similarly, we have heard suggestions of all sorts of shortages, based it seems mostly on the idea that the French might impede the flow of goods between Calais and Dover.It would not be the first time we had dealt with such issues. We had about 30 days of such delays in 2015. I remember queues of lorries, but I do not remember shortages of food or medicines.And on other issues, are the Europeans really going to pick a fight on data with the biggest IT power on the continent, on banking are they going to refuse to cooperate with the greatest financial ­centre in the world?Are the Greeks, Italians and Spaniards going to disadvantage the UK residents on whom many of their local economies depend? Or stop tourism? I think not.I suspect we are quite likely to have the odd hiccup when we leave the EU, but we will be able to cope, which is what Dominic Raab was demonstrating this week. And any problems we have will be over in months not years.So in 15 years’ time, far from worrying about Mr Hammond’s £80billion bill, the country will have trouble remembering what all the fuss was about.The biggest question will be whether we have made the most of the opportunities created by Brexit.And that is what we should worry about today, creating the circumstances where this great country can take its proper place in the world. We will only be able to do that if we allow ourselves the freedoms a clean Brexit will deliver.So my advice to all my old colleagues in Cabinet is simple: Ignore the misery merchants of the Treasury, stop fearing things that will never happen, and start planning for the real opportunities that this great country can grasp when it sets its mind to it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: benidorm women target british tourists disguise
story: Tourists are having their wallets, purses, passports and even luggage swiped as soon as they step off airport buses outside hotels.A Facebook page called Benidorm Robberies, Muggings and the Pea Men is highlighting the problem and warning travellers to stay alert.One victim wrote this week: “We arrived home yesterday to the UK after having an awful week last week in Benidorm.“My 84-year-old dad had his wallet stolen 5 minutes after getting off the coach outside Don Pancho Hotel and also on Wednesday afternoon in the indoor market my sister had her wallet stolen.“I would just like to say to all people going over there to be very, very careful.”Barbara said in a post: “So today after.an aborted landing at Alicante because of the weather and landed at Murcia we finally got to the Don Pancho 14 hours after leaving home, only to get off the coach and be immediately pick pocketed.”She managed to take back her purse and added: “She legged it luckily for her. What a start to a well-deserved holiday.”Another traveller said more than £1,000 in cash as well as valuable was taken from the safe in her room last week, adding that it seemed like an “inside job”.The Facebook page also has a rogues’ gallery of well-known con artists and pick pockets who operate in the resort.The page also warned about crooks operating on the beach.A post revealed: “Unfortunately it is too late for these holidaymakers but hopefully their experience will not be repeated.“They were a group of friends enjoying the beach. Some were sunbathing on loungers whilst others went in the sea.The sunbathers had a little nap and while their eyes were closed, the bags stored under the loungers were stolen!“These robbers are so quick and clever. Needless to say this nasty incident spoilt an otherwise lovely holiday.“Dont let it happen to you!”

title: jeremy corbyn faces official investigation into claim british zionists do not understand english irony after complaint made to labour
story: The veteran leftie has tried to clarify his remarks, but they have angered some of his MPs with one saying she felt “unwelcome in my own party” and another on the verge of quitting.And now the Labour Against Anti-Semitism group has reported Mr Corbyn “for anti-Semitism and for bringing the party into disrepute”.It comes after comments made by the Labour leader back in in 2013 were unearthed last week.In the latest chapter of an ongoing crisis he told a conference in London promoted by Hamas propaganda website, he said British “Zionists” - Jews who are strongly pro-Israel - did not want to study history or understand irony “despite having lived in this country all their lives”.Euan Philipps, a spokesperson for Labour Against Antisemitism, said: “The leader of our party must be subjected to the same scrutiny and procedures as any other member.“It is time for the Labour party to show it is serious about tackling antisemitism by immediately suspending Mr Corbyn and launching a full and independent investigation into his conduct.”The Conservative party has also reported Mr Corbyn to the parliamentary standards watchdog over the video of him at the Palestinian Return Centre.It comes after a recently departed Labour staffer who investigated complaints in the parry suggested if Mr Corbyn was not the leader he would be under investigation.Dan Hogan, a former member of their governance and legal unit, tweeted: “If Corbyn were any other member, he would have been suspended and investigated, and the [National Executive Committee] would nod through the bulging report on his offences.“He would join the long queue of other awful people waiting for a disciplinary hearing with the National Constitutional Committee.”Jewish Labour MP Luciana Berger said Corbyn’s 2013 remarks were “inexcusable comments” which made her feel “unwelcome in my own party”.And senior MP Mike Gapes was reported to have told colleagues he will quit the party, hours after he called Mr Corbyn a “racist anti-Semite”.Another of his colleagues in the Commons, John Mann, said the Labour leader risks killing the party “unless MPs and unions act to sort this racism out”.Mr Corbyn admitted he needs to be more careful with his language in a humiliating climb down over allegations of anti-Semitism.He insisted he was describing pro-Israel activists as Zionists, in the accurate political sense and not as a euphemism for Jewish people”.But said he will revise his use of the term Zionism because it had increasingly hijacked by anti-Semites”.But the Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell, one of his key allies, leapt to Mr Corbyns defence, and said the remarks had been taken out of context.The Mail on Sunday is reporting that the Jewish Labour Movement has held talks with the Community Security Trust – which guards the Jewish community in Britain – about providing minders for the event in Liverpool.A source told the paper: “This conference will be particularly tense as much of the worst anti-Semitic trolling on the internet has been traced back to hotspots in Merseyside.“The CST are reporting back with a full assessment of the security requirements. There is a real concern about safety.”One of the region’s MPs is Luciana Berger, the Parliamentary chair of the Jewish Labour Movement, has repeatedly been targeted for abuse.The former shadow minister for public health said she felt “unwelcome” in her own party after Mr Corbyn’s recent “inexcusable comments”.In response to the official complaint a party source told the Observer they were not aware of it, but a Labour spokesperson said: “The Labour party’s complaints procedure operates confidentially in the interests of fairness to all concerned.“This is to ensure protection of the personal data both for any members who make complaints, and for those to whom complaints relate.“This enables procedures to be followed properly. Therefore we do not comment on individual cases.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: monster squid beach wellington
story: Three brothers were out for a morning dive in Wellington when they came across the impressive creature.Daniel, Jack and Matthew Aplin were driving along on a track near Red Rocks on the citys south coast when they came across the beached cephalopods.The brothers said they had come across sharks while on their diving trips but had never seen a squid of that size.The trio contacted the National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research, who arranged to have the squid collected.A Department of Conservation spokesman said it was almost certainly a giant squid, the bodies of which washed up relatively regularly.Male giant squids can grow as large as 33ft long, and have suckers and barbs running down the length of their arms.The giant squid is the largest type of squid save for the colossal squid.They are chiefly hunted by sperm whales, but juveniles are occasionally hunted by deep-sea sharks.Rumours and sightings of giant squid as long as 66ft are widespread, but no specimens approaching this size have been scientifically documented.Studies show giant squid feed on deep-sea fish and other squid species.They catch prey using two tentacles, gripping it with serrated sucker rings, then bring it toward the powerful beak, and shred it before ingesting it.They are believed to be solitary hunters, as only individuals have ever been caught in fishing nets.Giant squid inhabit all the worlds oceans.Online commenter compared the brothers find to the colossal squid held at national museum Te Papa - which is over 17ft lo.Last year a 50ft squid washed up in Indonesia.

title: horror moment man 29 is crushed by 40 stone giant ball during spanish fiesta
story: The Madrid district of Mataelpino considered it safer and more animal-friendly to use the giant balls for the festival known as the boloencierro.The video was shot in 2017 , but portray an eerily similar situation to an accident at this years event, when two men were also injured.The video shows how dozens of revellers run down the hill in front of, and by the side of, the white ball as it gathers speed before the accident happens.The man does not get out of the way in time and is crushed against a wooden security fence.Emergency services immediately flock to the unconscious runner and fit a neck brace.The local council says it will be looking at security again as a matter of urgency.The giant ball is made of polystyrene but is so big that it weighs 40st, as much as some small bulls.The crowd is invited to test their running and dexterity skills by dodging the ball.However, two people were also injured in 2017, one of them seriously, and security measures were stepped up for 2018.Organisers said ball runners have to be aware of which direction the ball is going and if it is coming towards them, they should thrown themselves on the ground.

title: pm travel to africa brexit
story: And as the first British PM to visit Kenya in 30 years, she will address British troops training anti-jihadi forces in Nairobi.Mrs May said: “As we prepare to leave the European Union, now is the time for the UK to deepen and strengthen its global partnerships.This week I am looking forward to discussing how we can do that alongside Africa to help deliver important investment and jobs as well as continue to work together to maintain stability and security.”She was given a pre-visit boost as African politicians backed plans to use Brexit to forge closer links with the Commonwealth.Nigerian Presidential hopeful Atiku Abubakar said: “It is time to release the African lion economies such as Nigeria, South Africa and Kenya. We can be the catalyst for a worldwide Commonwealth trade deal with none of disadvantages of the EUs attempt to run Britain from Brussels.”The country’s former Vice President added: “My sincere belief is that Brexit can be a great force for good. It could blow down barriers which have prevented Nigeria and other countries from grasping their potential.”He went on: “time and again we are hit by EU tariffs on products such as sugar cane and rice. This is aimed at protecting European producers, often for products which are not farmed in Britain.”Downing Street hope the visit will help the UK forge better trade links with the continent that is home to 16 per cent of the world’s population but just three per cent of international trade.Mrs May will use a speech in Cape Town on Tuesday to make her pitch, saying: “Africa stands right on the cusp of playing a transformative role in the global economy, and as longstanding partners this trip is a unique opportunity at a unique time for the UK to set out our ambition to work even closer together.“A more prosperous, growing and trading Africa is in all of our interests and its incredible potential will only be realised through a concerted partnership between governments, global institutions and business.”Representatives from export giants JCB, Scotch whisky producers and infrastructure chiefs will travel with the PM.As will City bosses and the Lord Mayor of London.More than 640 troops, mostly black South Africans, died when the SS Mendi perished in the English Channel in 1917.They were on their way to join the Allied forces on the Western Front in World War One.It collided with a Royal Mail boat off the Isle of Wight, but no assistance was given to drowning victims.The bell has become a symbol of the South Africa’s First World War remembrance and protest at racial inequality.The recovered bell was donated anonymously to the BBC last year after the wreck was discovered in the 1970sMrs May will present it to President Ramaphosa in a ceremony at Cape Town on Tuesday – over a century after it was lost in a shipwreck.In 1995 the Queen and then South African leader Nelson Mandela unveiled a memorial to the Mendi victims.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu diplomats no flights no ships brexit
story: Senior diplomats told The Sun that Brits would face “no flights to and from the UK, no ships, no economic activity and no financial transactions” if we failed to agree a deal before we leave the bloc next March.One ambassador predicted the chaos for businesses and ordinary people in the UK would get so bad the situation would quickly become untenable for the Government.And a senior EU official said Brussels negotiators were banking on it being such a disaster that the “cycle of negotiations and the political dynamics will be taken over by the real world”. But leading Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg dismissed the “delusional”.He hit back at Brussels, telling The Sun: “It is wishful thinking by a EU establishment that has failed to notice that its grand scheme has failed economically, is devoid of democratic support and is increasing unpopular across the continent.EU sources also questioned Brexit secretary Dominic Raab’s upbeat assessment of how the UK would cope in the first few weeks of a no deal outcome. One said they “wouldn’t count on” his reassurance that Brits will still be able to enjoy a BLT sandwich in such a scenario.Last week the Government published a slew of notices warning people and businesses how to prepare for a crash out situation in March next year.Announcing them, Mr Raab dismissed suggestions the army and Air Force would have to be deployed to secure food and medicine supplies as “scare stories”. And in a bizarre pledge, he said Brits will “still be able to enjoy a BLT after Brexit”.But asked whether the UK Government could survive the first few days of a no deal exit, an EU ambassador told The Sun: “It’s not possible to have a no deal. There would be a massive outcry.“With even a no deal for one week, with no flights to and from the UK, no ships, imagine the economic loss of one week of no economic activity, no personal activity, no financial transactions. That would already be a disaster.”The diplomat added that Britain’s sluggish economic growth over the past year meant it was already “falling behind more and more” compared to the rest of the continent.The EU Commission has slashed its growth forecast for the UK to just 1.3 per cent for 2018, the joint lowest rate alongside struggling Italy.And EU officials believe that business pressure on Ministers to reach a compromise and avoid a crash out will crescendo in the next few months.A senior EU official told The Sun: “The moment the markets understand this is going in the wrong way, the cycle of negotiations and the political dynamics will be taken over by the real world.“In a few months the UK will have a credibility issue. The moment economic operators understand this is going wrong there will be events on the ground.”Meanwhile a former EU chief sparked outrage yesterday by claiming a no deal Brexit would trigger the break-up of the UK.Former European Council President Herman Van Rompuy said: “We could end up with a situation in which the EU27 becomes more united and a United Kingdom less united. This talk about a ‘no deal’ is the kind of nationalist rhetoric that belongs to another era.”THE Eurocrats are losing the plot.We’re used to their regular predictions that Britain will turn into the 10th circle of hell once we leave the EU. But even we’re taken aback by the ridiculous warning that we’ll have “no economic activity” the day after a clean break Brexit.These bizarre forecasts show the arrogance of those who rise to the top of the European tree.They genuinely believe that without their flag, their bureaucracy and their anthem that the continent will just fall apart.And it reveals their motives in the Brexit negotiations. To punish us, and send a message to anybody thinking of heading for the exit door – no matter how disastrous it is for the European economy.How are we supposed to negotiate in good faith? They can barely conceal their hope that the UK is going to slip into anarchy.The Government must continue to plan for a clean break. And treat everything Brussels says with not so much a pinch but a whole bucketload of salt.Meanwhile, for all their cocksure bravado, the EU is in all sorts of trouble.Unelected bosses in Brussels are in open warfare with the elected leaders of Poland and Hungary and are now fixing for a fight with Italy, too.Even the EU’s so-called ‘triumph’ in Greece will ring hollow to the 40% of youngsters there who are still out of work.Some ardent Remainers at home are still hoping that Britain might change its mind on leaving.But Brussels keeps proving that we’re better off out. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: public sector staff penion pay gap
story: A public sector employee currently earning the national average wage of £28,600 a year will retire with a £17,563-a-year pension.But someone working in the private sector on the same salary and making the same level of pension contributions would retire with just £6,412 a year.The private sector employee would have to save £3 in every £10 of their earnings - £8,606 a year - to retire with a pension as large as the public sector worker’s pension.The Taxpayers’ Alliance, which carried out the analysis, said the massive £11,000 a year gap laid bare how unjust the current pension system is for private sector workers, who end up picking up the bill for the “unfairly-generous” public sector pensions.Public sector pensions cost the public purse £38 billion last year - more than the entire UK defence budget. But despite this, the pensions are unfunded - meaning the whole bill has to be paid out of general taxation.Government liabilities for all exisitng unfunded pension obligations was a staggering £1.7 trillion in 2017. This is nearly as much as Britain’s official national debt of £1.8 trillion.The Taxpayers’ Alliance has called on ministers to stop raiding private pension pots and start funding public sector pensions to narrow the gap.Total pay in the public sector - including the value of pension contributions and bonuses, is on average 23 per cent higher than the private sector for comparable workers.Taxpayers’ Alliance boss John O’Connell blasted: “Workers in the private sector are paying for their public sector counterparts to enjoy a retirement they can only dream of, and that disparity has been brutally compounded over the years by politicians continuously launching raids on private pensions.“What’s more, pension promises made to public sector workers are unfunded and will continue to be paid out of general taxation - that is unsustainable as people are living a lot longer than when these schemes were cooked up.“To stop kicking the can down the road, reforms must ensure that new public sector pensions are properly funded and not paid for by the taxpayers of the future, namely our children and grandchildren.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pilot hailed a hero for safely landing faulty plane full of holidaymakers at full speed
story: The Jet2 airplane was on its way back from the Greek island of Crete to Leeds-Bradford airport when the drama happened.The captain flew around in circles for around an hour before a decision was made to divert the jet to Manchester airport, which has a longer runway.Some passengers fainted and others were sick during the drama at 3.30am on Sunday.Flight LS444 touched down at full speed as waiting fire engines sprayed the tyres with water to keep them cool.Passenger Jennifer Gilroy, 42, said passengers were told to adopt the brace position.She added:  We were bracing ourselves, you could hear everything screeching. It came in at full speed, seriously fast, hitting the ground.It felt like the plane wasn’t going to stop. It kept going, going and going.The pilot saved our lives, really. I was thinking if the plane catches fire, the jets are towards the back and would be the first to go. And we were sitting towards the back.It was a really good pilot, he kept us all calm. When we landed, he came out and spoke with every person.Another female passenger told on social media how she had to keep calm for her teenage son.She added: It was just awful and my first thought was, oh my God, the plane was going to set on fire but I had to be calm because my son was there.Im not a great flyer. Ive flown loads before but this time it was really stressful and I had to stop myself throwing up. It really has unsettled me and Im glad Im not going on holiday again too soon.The budget airline firm said flight LS444 from Heraklion in Crete to Leeds Bradford had to go into a holding pattern in order to assess a flap indication issue.A Jet 2 spokeswoman said  The decision was taken to divert into Manchester Airport as a precautionary measure due to it having a longer runway to facilitate a smooth landing.This latest incident with a Jet2 plane comes days after another jet travelling from Faro in Portugal to Leeds Bradford was forced to make an emergency landing in Bordeaux when cabin pressures dropped on August 10.On Thursday, another Jet2 plane was met with fire engines and ambulance crews on arrival after cabin pressures dropped again on another flight from Newcastle to Dalaman meaning that too had to make an emergency landing. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: man ate chicken nuggets chips twenty years therapy
story: Ryan Howarth, 21, of Andover, Hampshire, struggled to munch anything other than the classic kids meal since the age of four.His Selective Eating Disorder left him eating chicken nuggets and chips for 90 per cent of the last 17 years.On very rare occasions he could stomach steak, sausage, pasta and sweets.When offered other foods, the cinema host felt like they were so “foreign” that they were impossible for him to even try.He even wept for 20 minutes after his mum asked him to try root vegetable mash.His family kept reminding him about the health risks of his very unbalanced diet, which led him to finding a therapist.The treatment given by his therapist, Felix, was so effective he was persuaded to try out some other foods before he even left the room.Within minutes, Ryan was eating a iety of dishes with no hesitation.He said: “I used to just think that’s what my life was. I just ate the foods I wanted to.“The way I reacted when someone asked me to eat more was the same way most people would react if I asked them to eat an exotic food, like insects. It just felt so foreign to me.“My family started getting worried that my diet could cause health problems later on in life.“When I was still in the room with Felix, I was eating a bunch of different foods without hesitation.“Now I’m eating so many different things. There’s ones I like and there’s ones I don’t like, but I’m basically testing everything out.“It’s amazing how I’m enjoying foods I never expected I’d like. I never thought I’d like pineapple, but now it’s one of my favourites.Just one month after he’s been introducing these foods to his diet, Ryan already feels healthier.Before the switch, he had low energy levels, took a lot of vitamins to make up for the nutrients he wasn’t getting from his meals and ate a chocolate bar whenever he was feeling weak.Ryan said: “It’s amazing. I feel healthier and I feel like I have more energy throughout the day.“That was no way to live. I was eating candy to keep myself going. I had three cavities as a kid.”His mum Christiane, 45, has noticed a drastic change in his personality since taking up the new diet.She thinks he has been much more outgoing and friendlier than he had been lately.She said: “It’s incredible how much he has changed. He’s been more outgoing and he’s helping me with things around the house.“He recently went out to eat with his father. He hasn’t done that in years.“His eating disorder caused a barrier between the family. We had a lot of fights and heated discussions and we haven’t had any of those lately.“It’s amazing what is happening. My son is coming back.”

title: mums are getting babies high
story: Smoking cannabis leaves traces of the drug in breast milk for up to six days, it was revealed.Researchers in San Diego, California, said that tetrahydrocannabinol, cannabis’s psychoactive compound, was present in 63 per cent of breast milk samples studied.And cannabinoids, marijuanas active compounds, like to bind to fat molecules, which are abundant in breast milk.Lead researcher Dr Christina Chambers said: Paediatricians are often put into a challenging situation when a breastfeeding mother asks about the safety of marijuana use.We dont have strong, published data to support advising against use of marijuana while breastfeeding, and if women feel they have to choose, we run the risk of them deciding to stop breastfeeding - something we know is hugely beneficial for both mum and baby.The team looked at 54 samples from 50 women who used cannabis.The World Health Organization recommends exclusively breastfeeding a baby until is it six months old.Breast milk has been shown to improve a babys immune health and increased intelligence test results. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: flights grounded no deal brexit
story: There is no fall-back plan for air traffic control rights under World Trade Organisation rules in the event a deal cannot be struck with Brussels, the Institute for Economic Affairs warned.But the IEA stressed there are options available to the Government to put measures in place before March - and while it would “require flexibility on both sides”, there is an “overwhelming” mutual interest in protecting aviation from upheaval.In the first of a series of “no deal fear checker” reports released on Monday, it said the risk of flights being grounded was “conceivable, but still very unlikely”.The report said leaving the EU’s Single Aviation Market  in March without a replacement arrangement would see most UK-based airlines lose their operating licences for the 27 countries.Sam currently covers the UK’s rights to the so-called “freedoms of the air”, which include overflights of countries without landing and operating internal flights in foreign countries.The UK would also lose air traffic rights to countries including the United States, Canada and Switzerland because they had been made through the EU.In the report Julian Jessop, the IEA’s chief economist, wrote: “In summary, if there are no alternative arrangements in place, it would be as bad as the worst fears suggest: planes would not be allowed to fly.”However, the report said there were options open to the Government.It could “immediately” join other non-EU countries Norway and Iceland as members of the European Common Aviation Area , although this “off the shelf” option would mean following existing EU rules and “fudging” some of the Government’s Brexit “red lines”.Or negotiate a bespoke free trade agreement for aviation which would give the UK more control over the rules but could also mean “reduced access to the EU market” and “would also take longer to agree”. Negotiations would be made more difficult if the EU takes a hard line in the event of a fractious no-deal Brexit, it adds.There are also three “reasons for optimism” that the worst-case scenario would not be realised, it found.The UK is a world leader in aviation, which means it has “plenty of leverage” as the largest market in Europe and the third largest in the world.The report also says there are strong mutual interests in a beneficial arrangement: “Grounding UK airlines would be hugely damaging for the EU economy, particularly in areas like tourism.“And, of course, foreign airlines presumably want to continue to fly to and from the UK as well.“Since these agreements are reciprocal, it is unlikely that other countries would deny the UK the most important rights when they would then almost certainly lose them too.”It continues: “Third, even if this is left to the last moment, there are several quick fixes.“In particular, the UK and EU [or a third country like the US] could agree at least a temporary extension of the current arrangements by something as simple as a memorandum of understanding.“The key question for the EU is whether the necessity of keeping planes flying outweighs any threats to the integrity of the single market or the risks of giving the UK special treatment - the answer must surely be ‘yes’.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Sunday's downpours forced the cancellation of the Silverstone GoPro British Grand Prix MotoGP.Silverstone managing director Stuart Pringle made a personal apology in an online post, saying race fans were "subjected to the most extraordinarily long wait in the foulest of British weather conditions, which ultimately resulted in no race at all".
